story:
The Project:

The goal of this project is to enhance opportunities for community organizing among Central Asian labor migrants in Russia, with a focus on citizens of Tajikistan, through the use of photography and graphic design. Through the recruitment of several migrants to participate in the project, we look to teach and coach the migrants about photography and basic graphic design to create organizational flyers and other forms of graphic communications to tell their stories along their journeys to Russia.


This project will collaborate with Zamira Djabarova, a native of Tajikistan, who is conducting a traditional research project (that is already fully-funded and underway) that seeks to identify existing organizing efforts among labor migrants in Russia and ways they could be enhanced, specifically in Sochi. Being the location of the next Winter Olympics, it is paramount that migrants' rights be sustained due to the nature of the site. Rut Perez-Studer will collaborate with Zamira to bring an "artistic-visual" element to her research that will bring light to the struggles of organizing and the plight of the migrants in Sochi.


***Please scroll to the bottom for other (non-financial) ways to help.***

The Story:


The grandeur and spirit of the Olympic Games is one that inspires the imagination, at times sends chills over oneâ€™s body. The images that come to mind are athletes on the podiums, shots of crossing finish lines, celebrations of a team reaching their goals, the trials and tribulations of the struggles and successes of the athletes. 

Now, we see another side of the gamesâ€¦ images of the stage for the Olympics being built, scaffolding lined with workers, the unsafe work conditions. There are pictures of the squalor of the migrant workers on the construction sites, sequences of their long journeys from home and the hardships endured.


We look to the second principle in the Fundamental Principles of Olympism, the Olympic Charter states that:  â€œThe goal of Olympism is to place sport at the service of the harmonious development of man, with a view to promoting a peaceful society concerned with the preservation of human dignity.â€


Tajikistan is a country that once formed part of the Soviet Union. Today it is one of the most migration-dependent countries in the world. Traditionally, it is a country with a surplus labor force and is increasing each year. The unemployment rate is currently at 40%. Economic desperation and high unemployment rates have forced 800,000 to migrate, with unofficial figures standing as high as 1.5 million people.


Russia is a primary destination country for migrants from Tajikistan due to familiarity with language, labor needs and ease on work visas. Although this familiarity is helpful, Tajiks suffer many abuses along their journeys to Russia and once they have arrived to their final destinations. In order to increase migrant communitiesâ€™ influence in protection of their own rights, there is a need for self-empowerment. Despite existing benefits of unions and organized groups to advocate for improved conditions, there is limited organizing among migrants from Tajikistan. 

 

The Plan:

This phase of the project begins in March-April of 2012, a month after Zamira has established her in-country investigation in Tajikistan. Rut plans on joining Zamira to support her efforts by documenting the work (film + photography) and starting to work with migrants who have already been recruited to travel to Sochi. Once in Tajikistan, we will have class twice a week with support from local migrant support organizations.


After several weeks of training, and as migrants start to leave for the work season, we will go to Sochi to meet back with the migrants we trained in Tajikistan. If the conditions are favorable in Sochi (Phase II of the project) we look to expand the project and create some footage for short clips to be used by international awareness organizations. Once finished in Sochi, we plan on returning to the States to put together a photo series of the images created by the migrants and short video clips to further support their efforts.

 

The Need:

Here is the deal... We need over $15,000 to get this project underway and be able to be in Tajikistan by April to begin classes before the migrants leave for Russia.


What needs to happen before all of this is: gathering cameras (for migrants to use) and related equipment, applying for travel visas, obtaining permits to travel with the equipment and purchasing the travel tickets. So, this contribution will pay for these items, as well as in-country expenses such as rental of spaces to hold workshops, photography materials for migrants to work with, translation services and computer use, communication expenses to get the word out, room and board in Russia (in Tajikistan we would rely on friends and family).

We know that this is a rich story with the Olympic element, but it is difficult to raise money from foundations at this stage of the game. We are reaching out for help from PEOPLE LIKE YOU â€“ people who love the challenging stories intermingled with the arts and believe in people being triumphant. Your money will help fund photography, graphic design and other organizing/ advocacy workshops for Tajik migrants and get enough photographs to create a larger story, which are the elements that foundations like to see before placing their support.

Our total cost for the entire project - complete with the final creation of the report, supporting images to create a photo journal, exhibits and short clips of video footage - is over $60,000, so all of this IndieGoGo money is vital for our ability to make this happen.
 
*We will send a financial report to all contributors upon completion of the project.

 

Meet the Team:

Rut Perez-Studer is a specialist with experience in the industries of design- marketing, construction-architecture who advocates for the protection of laborers within this industry through community-social activism and immigration-labor protection.

 

Zamira Djabarova is an independent development expert working with the United Nations Entity for Gender Equality and the Empowerment of Women. Her areas of expertise include migration, social protection, womenâ€™s rights and aid effectiveness. 

 

Sheila Aminmadani is an educator, activist and community engagement specialist who has worked in human rights, social justice advocacy and youth development for nearly ten years.


Other ways you can help...

Used Camera Campaign: We are in need of used digital cameras that the migrants can use for learning photography and uploading their images, as well as documenting their journeys. If you are able to donate a camera, please contact Rut Perez-Studer by email at rperez-studer@hotmail.com. We would like to obtain at least 10 if possible.


Outreach: Please get the word out on any social media sources that you have such as facebook, blogs, twitter, etc.

story:
The Heritage Society of Austin is asking for your financial support to develop an online app featuring walking tours of historic Austin architecture.

We have collected a large number of stories and photographs about Austin's most important historic architectural structures. We feel that publishing online in App format will connect this information with a young audience and further the cause of historic preservation. We are developing an interactive platform for people to be able to explore Austin via audio recordings, photographs and geo-targeting that will also allow users to comment, add information and share additional photographs.

In addition to helping to spread our mission of historic preservation, the development of the app can help with our education outreach programs and also can be a mechanism for ongoing financial support of our non-profit organization.

Notes: Heritage Society of Austin will be renamed as Preservation Austin in Fall 2012.  The Austin Convention & Visitors Bureau is a partner with the Heritage Society of Austin in presenting the Historic Austin App.

story:
Tom Adam Photography

I've spent years working in IT for somebody else, and could only do photography in my "free time."  As I thought about what makes me happy, I realized how much more fulfilled I feel helping people document their special moments, particularly their weddings.  A photograph is not just something you put in a book, or even on a wall; it should be a time-machine that takes you back to that moment - the sights, smells, and emotions of that unique time.  It can also become complete personalized art.
 
With hearts in our throats, my wife and I are looking to expand to a full time photography business. We're so proud of the work we've done so far, which you can see at Tom Adam Photography (weddings/fashion portraits) and Life in Motion by Amber (portraits/lifestyle).  But to go further and produce the highest quality images and products, we need to add and upgrade equipment.
 

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking for your support to help us upgrade our equipment.  Our goal of $3500 will help us purchase our primary camera body - a Canon 5diii.  Any additional funds will help us get additional lenses and professional lighting equipment.

As a thank-you for your support and belief in our talents, we would like to provide you with some of the fine art photographs I have taken, or even do a portrait session or wedding with you, if you live in the Eastern Iowa area. (Heck, if you're willing to pay travel expenses, we'll come do your shoot ANYWHERE.)

You can see some of the fine art pictures here.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love what we do and want to help but are unable to financially, you can still help by promoting our business and our project, by sharing this link with your friends and families, on Facebook and on Twitter.  Just sharing will encourage us and hold us strong in the belief that we can do amazing and beautiful things, and bring those things to everybody.

story:
Art For Shelters will give 250 paintings to New York City shelters in the next 12 months with your support.

 
OUR MISSION : Art For Shelters (AFS) gives the gift of art, creating a vision for social responsibility. 

OUR PROJECT: Art For Shelters will create and donate 250 paintings to New York City Shelters in the next 12 months. 

We donate vibrant art work to shelters, in order to inspire and uplift the spirit of victims of domestic violence and their children, victims of child abuse and sex trafficking as well as homeless teens living in shelters. Similar to the business model of our hero, (Blake Mycoskie of Toms Shoes), Art For Shelters is based on a one for one concept. For each work of art sold, artwork of equal value will be donated to a shelter. A "special thanks" plaque engraved with the buyer's name will accompany the donated art acknowledging their special participation. Once we meet our funding goal, we will send you images and videos via Indiegogo of the AFS team delivering the paintings to the shelters. 

OUR FUNDING: Upon funding $40,000, we will be able to accomplish the following:

* create the first 25 paintings for New York City shelters

* purchase supplies for the remaining 225 paintings

* execute the public relations launch campaign

* launch the marketing and sales campaign for AFS

* launch a social media campaign for AFS

* transportation costs to deliver paintings to NYC shelters

OUR ART:

AFS will donate modern paintings by artist, Gina Raphaela, a New York City based artist and co-founder of AFS. Gina's work is held in private collections throughout the world. Her work has also been featured in publications such as VAGA and NY Arts. Her exhibit, Love or Fear, opened last month in Chelsea with Nona Hendryx. Critics hailed Gina’s exhibition: “a very fluid and provocative show." Her constructive sculpture, Timed, “a life size figure covered with 16,000 mini-marshmallows brilliantly emphasized the universal desire to look young." After donating 250 of Gina's paintings in the first year, AFS will bring other artists on board and expand to shelters throughout the United States. Our long-tern vision is a global operation where art is donated to shelters and orphanages around the world; as well as developing an educational project that allows Art For Shelters to bring a day of making art to the people living in these shelters. 

OUR DREAM: By participating in our funding goal, we hope you will become inspired to look at what you have right in front of you; then create it, donate it and uplift those who need it most. Imagine how your own business or place of employment can create a one for one concept. Do it....then do a little happy dance.

We believe social responsibility is cool. 

OUR PRIZES: See details of our prizes to the right and some images in gallery. After our funding goal is met, we will reach out to all of our generous supporters and obtain all details necessary to fulfill your prizes!

OUR BIO's

THE FOUNDERS:

Gina Raphaela is a New York based artist influenced by her bold and vibrant Sicilian heritage. From Fellini films to the deep red sauces of her grandmother’s cooking, Gina's art is a color-filled memory reflecting passionate expression. Her work has been exhibited in New York, Los Angeles, Miami, Washington DC, and Tokyo.

Gina's first solo show in Los Angeles, LIFE SAVERS, a series of vivid abstract paintings with resin, sold out opening night. Her recent exhibit, LOVE OR FEAR, opened at CATM Gallery in Chelsea to great acclaim. The Constructive Sculpture Series, an exploration of the 21st century woman, depicts sexuality, identity and power. These sculptures represent the need to blow up cultural standards of women that still exist. "How can we be so admired and adored for our beauty yet be marginalized at the same time?"

As an entrepreneur, Gina launched a design and painting firm LG DESIGN in Los Angeles. Her creative talents have also landed her in front of the camera in commercial and print work for such clients as McDonald’s, Charmin and American Express.

Gina is the co-founder of Art For Shelters. Gina's vision is to donate her original art  to every shelter in New York City, then expand throughout the United States and ultimately have a global presence around the world.


TINA ALEXIS ALLEN

Tina Alexis Allen is an actress, writer, producer, entrepreneur and a GLAAD award nominee.

Tina attended college on a basketball scholarship at the University of Maryland and received her MBA from Mount Saint Mary’s. She moved to New York City to begin her career in fashion. Within a brief period of time, Tina was managing the sales divisions and marketing operations for top contemporary designers.

After a fast climb up the corporate ladder, Tina decided to pursue an acting career, which has lead to many starring roles on the stage and screen.

Most recently, Tina was Off-Broadway in the World Premiere of Tennessee Williams's, In Masks Outrageous and Austere at The Culture Project. Her solo show, Secrets Of A Holy Father, which she also wrote, was workshopped at The Cherry Lane Theatre.

Other Off-Broadway credits include Susan in the premiere of Charles Mee’s Fire Island.  The New York Times praised Tina's work, “Ms. Allen is an actor of great conviction;” Lydia in Underground at The Beckett Theatre. In Los Angeles, Tina wrote and performed her 12 character one woman show, Irresistible, in which critics said, “her character work rivals that of Lily Tomlin.”  Tina was nominated for a GLAAD award along side Jane Lynch.

Highlights from her screen work include writing, directing and acting opposite Teri Garr in God Out The Window; the Slamdance Jury Prize Nominated, Phantom Pain, which she starred in and produced; and the indie films Last Rite, Bushwick, and Molly. Her screenplay, Bittersweet, was a finalist for the Sundance Writer’s Lab. Tina made her television debut on Touched By An Angel, and can be seen as “Dr. Mills” in The Onion News Network on IFC.

Tina is the co-founder of Art For Shelters. Her bold vision is that every company become socially responsible, giving and receiving in equal measure.

story:
Once upon a time...
There was a group of SCAD students in an event planning class. The class was tasked with creating an exciting, educational and social event for the community in Savannah, Georgia. These students, passionate about art and creativity, wanted to produce the most spectacular event EVER to be held in Savannah...but then they realized they only had nine weeks and a limited budget.

So they thought, and pondered, and thought some more until one student shouted out with excitement: we know that this would be a great event for the community...so lets ask them for help!!

And so these hard working, busy bee SCAD students have been planning and coordinating for an event that can bring together their community by sharing ideas about wellness and creativity and holding free activities to engage their friends and neighbors, and showcasing local organizations such as the Georgia Art Therapy Association but they need your help!

The class needs donations to make this event a success. Please make a donation today! Proceeds will go to the Georgia Art Therapy Association. Help us get creactive!
 
WHAT is creactive?
creactive: mind, body, art is an event that explores the connection between mind, body and creative expression. We invite the entire Savannah community to join us on Saturday, May 25th, for physical activities,  art activities, discussions, food, and film that fosters creativity and wellness.

WHO is invited?
This event is free and open to the public. We invite SCAD students as well as any creative people, active bodies, couch potatoes, men, women, children, students, teachers and professionals.

WHERE does it take place?
TBA – Savannah

WHEN does creactive take place?
Join us on Saturday, May 25th (time details to come)
WHY should you help?

We are students that seek to provide opportunities free of charge to the community. We want to create a community that is full of creativity and wellness.

HOW can you help?
You can make this event a success! We would like to shine light on the Georgia Arts Therapy Association (GATA). GATA acilitates networking and collaboration among art therapists in Georgia in addition to providing continuing education, training, and workshops with the aim of advancing the field of art therapy, and sharing it with others. Please give to our campaign to support our event and this amazing organization.

Can't give us any of your dough? Help us spread the word instead! Head to our facebook page, share it with your friends and attend our event!

PERKS!
Any funds raised go towards putting on this FREE event. Additional proceeds will benefit the Georgia Art Therapy Association.

Give and Get. Donate to our campaign and we will give you some cool gear.

$1 - good karma & facebook thank you shout out!
$15- water bottle & creactive sticker
$25- creactive tee shirt + water bottle & sticker
$50 - All the above + your name spelled out by our class using yoga positions (we've been practicing)

Locals can pick up their perks on the day of the event.

Please make a donation today! Proceeds will go to the Georgia Art Therapy Association. Help us get creactive! WHAT is creactive?creactive: mind, body, art is an event that explores the connection between mind, body and creative expression. We invite the entire Savannah community to join us on Saturday, May 25th, for physical activities,  art activities, discussions, food, and film that fosters creativity and wellness.WHO is invited?This event is free and open to the public. We invite SCAD students as well as any creative people, active bodies, couch potatoes, men, women, children, students, teachers and professionals.WHERE does it take place?TBA – SavannahWHEN does creactive take place?Join us on Saturday, May 25th (time details to come)WHY should you help?We are students that seek to provide opportunities free of charge to the community. We want to create a community that is full of creativity and wellness.HOW can you help?You can make this event a success! We would like to shine light on the Georgia Arts Therapy Association (GATA). GATA acilitates networking and collaboration among art therapists in Georgia in addition to providing continuing education, training, and workshops with the aim of advancing the field of art therapy, and sharing it with others. Please give to our campaign to support our event and this amazing organization.Can't give us any of your dough? Help us spread the word instead! Head to our facebook page, share it with your friends and attend our event!PERKS!Any funds raised go towards putting on this FREE event. Additional proceeds will benefit the Georgia Art Therapy Association.Give and Get. Donate to our campaign and we will give you some cool gear.$1 - good karma & facebook thank you shout out!$15- water bottle & creactive sticker$25- creactive tee shirt + water bottle & sticker$50 - All the above + your name spelled out by our class using yoga positions (we've been practicing)Locals can pick up their perks on the day of the event.

story:
The London Analogue Festival

 In the 21st century, every possible thing is digital, and yet people are always talking about the irreplaceable richness of analogue: the depth of sound, the clarity of colour – and it’s easy to spot the difference between digital recordings and professional films.

 

In an age of plastic and quick fixes, we’re starting the London Analogue Festival (LAF) in order to celebrate things that are labour-intensive, equipment designed with care and built to last, techniques that demand time and attention, and results that are nothing short of captivating.

 

 

We’re not just talking about sound and pictures. The LAF will be set in historic Deptford, in the kinds of London buildings tourists dream of visiting but seldom get to see: The Old Police Station, Deptford Town Hall, and the Amersham Arms.

 

 

International artists and producers will bring moving images, photography and sound art to South East London. Encouraging participation, the festival will offer a wide array of workshops, discussions, networking opportunities, and some remarkable door prizes. Our festival partners include Goldsmiths University of London, Lomography, Silverprint, The Impossible Project, Moo.com, and Room66.

 

 

 

With all of that in hand, what could we possibly need? Rent, insurance, printed promotional materials (We are old-fashioned, after all.), programmes, maps, the cost of ferrying around very expensive equipment, and those infamous ‘incidentals’ that always pop out of the closet the day before an opening.

 

With no fee for entry, this festival will put the beauty of analogue within everybody’s reach. Most of the workshops will be free, as well. That means we can’t offer entrance waivers in thanks. Fortunately, we’re more creative than that. If the rewards weren’t unique, then this wouldn’t be analogue – and it is.

 

None of this money will stay with us. Every penny will go to making the LAF all it should be: a collection of memorable events, and the first year of an annual festival every analogue-lover will want to attend.

 

Thank you in advance for your help, and we look forward to seeing you in September!



 

UPDATES

As partner of the festival, Room66 will share a select space within the London Analogue Festival venues to showcase an exhibition with emerging London artists who make diverse and contemporary art, following the ethos of the LAF of being open to all. The artists involved includes Vinny Montag; who's surrealistic and ready-made objects leave the viewer smiling in wonderment, and artist Henri Ghosn; who creates real life London art-works that make you re-think the city.

story:
Robotomo® 

Positive. Earth. Revolution.

Robotomo® is the Revolutionary Design Startup of Artist and Designer Nicola Capiluppi. All design products are conceived, designed and Made in Italy!

  • Nicola Capiluppi aka Robotomo is an international artist who created and defined a new step of human evolution: Robotomo®
  • The goal campaign is start to produce Robotomo® mod. 005 Sculpture Neacklace. Conceived, designed and handcrafted in Italy, size 40 mm  x 40 mm in pure hig-grade Stainless Steel 18/10 AISI 304.
  • Your help is very important to start a New Italian Design!
  • Starting to produce Robotomo® Neacklace Sculpture I need 6000 euro
  • Help me to make this dream real!

The Impact

  • Robotomo® in an Italian Art Design Made in Italy and an Artistic expression: This is the biggest value!
  • Robotomo® is registered Trademark  and the designer Nicola Capiluppi is drawing other concept products so help him! 
  • Robotomo® represent the change I made in my life to reinvent my future!              Robotomo®. Positive. Earth. Revolution.
  • Robotomo® is completely Made in Italy! Robotomo® respect the value of the people, the value of our planet (no chemical or toxic production system), Robotomo® is the positive change we must made!                                           Robotomo®.                                                                                                                           Positive. Earth. Revolution.

Risks & Challenges

  • Minimum risk. The first production will be of 1000 pieces
  • Robotomo® will be distribuited with different marketing channel:                   Micro distribuition channel and big distribuition channel.
  • 400 Robotomo® neacklace Sculpture are bookable here investing                       45 euro in this crazy project! 
  • Robotomo® wants to become the first  real Italian Art Factory!

Other Ways You Can Help Robotomo®

  • Share the Robotomo® funrising on the social network                                              and invite your friends to do the same!

story:
Who is Dr Dax? 

People like Dr Dax helped make the world a friendlier place for those of us, our friends and family members who may experience mental ill health during our lives.

Dr Eric Cunningham Dax was a pioneering psychiatrist who helped reform the mental health system in Australia. He introduced far-reaching innovations that gave dignity and a quality of life to patients that had previously been sadly lacking. He started community-based services such as Lifeline - a world’s first at the time. He fought hard against the stigma around mental illness throughout his long career.

Dr Dax also believed in the value of art and creativity, and initiated art programs for patients in institutions as far back as the 1940s. He salvaged many artworks from skip bins and rubbish heaps as the institutions closed down in the 90s - these formed the kernel of the Cunningham Dax Collection – one that has grown to around 15,000 works today.

There is still a long way to go. Stigma and social isolation still keep people ‘locked out’ in many ways. In exhibiting the artworks to the community, The Dax Centre proudly carries on the legacy of Dr Eric Cunningham Dax.


The Project

Raw Emotion: Contemporary and Historic Works from the Cunningham Dax Collection.

A selection of artworks will form a survey exhibition of the Cunningham Dax Collection, a collection of over 15,000 artworks created by people with a lived experience of mental illness or trauma. Within the exhibition, the Collection’s most recent acquisitions, donated by artists within the last two years, will share the gallery space with the Collection’s most historic works, created in psychiatric hospitals and institutions in the 1950s and 1960s, collected by psychiatrist and founder of The Dax Centre, Dr Eric Cunningham Dax. The works will reflect both the historic foundation of the Collection, along with it’s continued engagement with artists and community groups today.

Employing diverse media and techniques, the contemporary and historic works reveal the artists’ raw emotional experiences, often using the physical body in various forms of self-portraiture. These works are a testament to the enduring importance of creativity, self-reflection, and the power of the subconscious.

Included in the contemporary acquisitions are artists David Apostol; Alison Colvin; Graeme Doyle; Rebecca Duke; Kallena Kucers; Emma McEvoy; John Puli; Ruth Rich; and Elizabeth Turnbull.

What We Need & What You Receive

The funds raised will allow The Dax Centre to curate and install the exhibition, and open the gallery to the public through to February 2015.

Raising one third of the goal will allow the exhibition to be curated and installed. Remaining funds raised will allow Raw Emotion to be exhibited in the gallery through to February.

We will be offering free exhibition entry, VIP invitations to the opening night, Behind the Scenes Tours, personalised artworks, and even Dax Gallery hire.

The Impact

With each visitor who leaves with greater insight, understanding and empathy we take a step closer as a community, to breaking down the stigma and social isolation that still keep so many ‘locked out’. 

Art is a powerful way of communicating concepts that involve the workings of the mind and the experience of emotion, and exhibiting these works represents a powerful opportunity for those with an experience of mental illness or psychological trauma to share their stories.

The Dax Centre exhibited works from the Collection, and run public and education programs from its gallery in the Melbourne Brain Centre since 2011. These have been funded independently until now, which is why we are running this crowd funding campaign. 

The works of the Cunningham Dax Collection are too important to be kept from the community! Please contribute what you can to make this important project happen.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you aren't able to contribute you can still help by sharing information about this project using the Share features, telling people about it and signing up to our Mailing List via the website www.daxcentre.org.

    PS. You can donate using a credit card even if you don't have a Paypal account! Simply choose the option in Paypal that says 'pay with a credit or debit card'. 

    Thank you for your support!!

    ABN.  76 147 566 792
    The Dax Centre is a non-profit organisation that relies on public support. Donations over $2 are tax deductible.

story:
► Short Summary

We are a group of recently graduated young artists and designers with a mission – to help other artists develop their passion for experiment and mingle with think-alikes from around the globe. To achieve our goal, we and our non-profit organization NO Studio created NE Fest.

----------

NE Fest is an international festival for independent experimental art, held in Sofia, Bulgaria, organized by the Bulgarian foundation NO Studio with the cooperation of the Bulgarian National Culture Fund, the National Academy of Arts (NAA), Sofia University „St. Kliment Ohridski“ (SU), and Culture Center SU.

NE Fest shows YOUNG EXPERIMENTAL ARTISTS from around the globe. It presents a diverse spectrum of media from the fields of contemporary art, theatre, dance, video, music and literature. 

►► NE FEST 1:

The festival was launched in September 10th – 14th, 2013. Despite the financial hurdles, the efforts of the strongly motivated, energetic team brought about several very successful events - EXHIBITIONS, WORKSHOPS, CONCERTS, PRESENTATIONS, DISCUSSIONS, FLASH MOBS at 8 locations in Sofia, with 42 participants from 9 different countries.

NE Fest 1 (2013); Installation exhibition;
Gallery "Glossary depot"; photo: MEM Studio

NE Fest 1 (2013); Photography exhibition;
Rubber Gallery; photo: Marica Kolcheva

Since then, NE Fest has gathered a lot of friends and fans in the social network. It has become very famous in facebook and has nearly 5000 FANS. What is more, the festival’s second call for participation was selected as a featuring open call on and was sent to 30 000 + web subscribers.

►► NE FEST 2:

The second edition of the festival will take place from 15th – 30th SEPTEMBER 2014, under the theme “POINTS OF VIEW”. This time NE Fest will consist of two parts: a festival program (15 – 21 September), in which the creative team will be showing the public different viewpoints of the presented works by means of SCENOGRAPHIC VISUAL EFFECTS, and an exhibition program (22 – 30 September) – the artworks shown in a more traditional way. The events will be situated in the new alternative culture center in Sofia – ZONA CULTURA (located in an old factory).


Preview for one of the festival's scenery versions

After the successful open call, more than 70 PARTICIPANTS from 28 COUNTRIES (Austria | Bosnia and Herzegovina | Bulgaria | Canada | Croatia | Denmark | France | Germany | Greece | Indonesia | Iran | Italy | Japan | Lithuania | Luxemburg | Macedonia | Netherlands | Norway | Peru | Poland | Romania | Scotland | Spain | Sweden | Turkey | UK | Ukraine | USA) were selected! They will take part in the exhibitions or in the performances, concerts, theatres, poetic readings, and video projections program of the festival.

----------

► What We Need & What You Get

Since we are a non-profit cultural organization, all of the money we raise from this campaign will go directly back into the creative economy.  We were granted $2,000 from the Bulgarian National Culture Fund for building the scenery for the festival but WE NEED ANOTHER $4,000 TO MAKE NE FEST HAPPEN! 

  1. The first 2000 $ we raise will go for the technical set up of the festival: lights, multimedia, speakers, and power.
  2. The next 1000 $  will go for the logistics of the exhibition and events.
  3. Artists' expenses (such as travel expenses, accommodation, etc.) and hiring additional staff will be covered with the final sum of 1000 $ and any amount exceeding our goal of 4000 $.

Budget graph

As an award for your help, we have personally created all of the suggested gifts - Thank You cards, elaborate pop-up cards, catalogues, videos, etc.


Pop-up Thank You card

And for those of you, who could afford а higher contribution, we have a very special SPONSORSHIP PACKAGE:

  • All Festival VIP pass;
  • your organization listed as a sponsor;
  • including your logo on the website and program;
  • a sponsor page on the site profiling your organization;
  • NE Fest catalogue;
  • a charitable Donation Certificate in your name.

----------

      ► The Impact

      NE Fest 1 was a test for us - whether we had the will and motivation to create something out of nothing in the name of art. We started the preparation for the festival having no money and no experience. Luckily, we met the support of the Student Council at the Art Academy in Sofia, Bulgaria who donated a small amount of money to our project. Even though it was a difficult task to accomplish, in the end, we did a great job and what is more, we learned that if you believe and work hard enough, anything is possible.

      After almost a year of constant work on the second edition of NE Fest, we are still missing the financial stability. And this time we are standing up pledging for your support. YOUR HELP WILL MAKE THE DIFFERENCE and contribute to the development of a new trend of art - the independent experimental art, and its evergrowing followers.

      If we have a successful campaign, we will become one of the few festivals in the world and the first in Bulgaria raised by the public.

      WE RELY ON YOU!

      ----------

      ► Risks & Challenges

      Since we have already successfully pulled off the pilot edition of the festival, we have gathered the valuable experience required to foresee and avoid many of the risks and challenges a project of this caliber implies.  The main hurdle we cannot overcome on owr own yet is securing the financial side of the festival and this was the reason we came to www.indiegogo.com to find you.

      ----------

      ► Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you cannot afford funding our project, you can still help us spread the word about the festival and share our campaign and facebook page.

      (Please, use the Indiegogo share tools.)

      If you like NE Fest, make sure your friends and family like it, too! :)

      THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT, FRIENDS!

      Yours faithfully,
      NE Fest team
                ☼

story:
Short Summary

As one of the inventors of the Swing Game, legendary reptile collector, and chief superman underwear wearer, Aaron Jed was a seminal creator of the culture of Claymont and of the dreams held within our distant childhoods.  Presently, this poet gardener of space and time cannot afford to travel from Portland, where he now resides, to Claymont, and without him the reunion would be incomplete.  Help bring him to the Claymont Kids Reunion (August 22nd to 24th). 

What We Need & What You Get

We need enough money to:

  • Buy Aaron a plane ticket from PDX to Dulles.  Donations in miles are also accepted separate from the campaign.
  • Enough for cab fare and lunch.
You get:
  • So much.

The Impact

The impact can not be measured in words.  It must be experienced.

    Risks & Challenges

    Aaron may not show up.  He could light things on fire.  He could get too drunk to suitably hold a conversation with any of you.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Donate miles.  Pack him a lunch.  Give him a ride somewhere.

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Join The Klawedis Journey.

UPDATE: The documentary for our first artist, Carlos Tello, is live! Check it out below. 

It's official! Our website has launched. Visit klawedis.com to view all available art as well as the story of current artist, Carlos Tello,


 

What is Klawedis?

The Klawedis Project gives you the opportunity to support global artists and their communities while buying affordable art.

How?

Klawedis will source art from talented global artists and bring it to you through the Klawedis website. Buying their work gives them the exposure and compensation they need.

But how do you get the art?

The Klawedis Journey has two phases.

The first phase will rely on our travel in search of unique and undiscovered art, creating a new audience for our global artists throughout the Klawedis community. 

The second phases enables Art Ambassadors to discover unique and authentic pieces, and share them with the larger Klawedis community. Art Ambassadors will receive a percentage of each of their discovered artists’ sales.

What is an Art Ambassador?

It could be you! Or anyone that is traveling that comes across a piece that the world needs to see. We will work with you to procure the art and give you a percentage of the sale while fully compensating the artist and giving them the opportunity to grow their audience.

What about the name Klawedis?

We picked Klawedis because it’s not a word in any language. It’s sidewalk spelled backwards, but also reflects how art doesn't need a language to tell a story.

The Inspiration

The Klawedis journey was inspired by a trip to Cozumel, Mexico. Exploring the small town we came across a back alley and walked inside a tiny shop. Inside was an incredible art studio with unique handmade pieces in all sizes. The artist was in the back creating the skull and watermelon piece shown here. We learned that he had been painting for 30 years in the same location. Unique canvas paintings inspired by the culture of Mexico, we had to buy one! Not on the main strip, he gets the occasional tourist customer but still struggles to sustain an income. We felt talent like this is often overlooked and created Klawedis to share the talent and story of artists like him with the world.

 

What is sidewalk art?

Sidewalk art has a story. It's that amazing piece that can only be found off the beaten path. Each piece is truly unique and reflects not only the artist but also the culture. Our goal is to bring you the piece along with their story. The art featured will be paintings, photography, jewelry, and pottery.

The Klawedis Website.

The Klawedis Website will serve to showcase art and artists from around the world while providing a marketplace for you to buy affordable art. Video diaries documenting the personal Journey of the artists will accompany the pieces and provide more depth to the background of the art and artist you choose to support. As the Klawedis Project grows the website will also support submissions from world travelers like yourself that find an artist in need of greater exposure.

Where does the money go?

The funds we raise will go towards the procurement of art from around the world and building a website capable of displaying these pieces.  In the first phase all of the art will be purchased on location and resold via the website. As we build relationships and find Art Ambassadors the cost of acquisition will be reduced.

Where are we going in year one? 

Central America - Mexico, Belize, Panama

South America - Columbia, Brazil, Argentina

Asia - Japan, Laos, Vietnam

Africa - South Africa, Kenya, Madagascar 

Who are these people with this global art mission with a funky name?

We met one fateful night 3 summers ago in NYC. We connected instantly and knew we had each met our match. We dating long distance for two years while Deaglan traveled, competing for the United States rowing team and I worked in finance in New York. In the spring of 2012, I moved to San Francisco and so ended the many nights apart, but not our traveling. After a year enjoying the Cali life, we moved back East to Brooklyn and got engaged. After ‘retiring’ from rowing Deaglan joined the technology sector. With a passion for global initiatives we created Klawedis to affect positive change in both art and communities. 

What are the perks for supporters?

Our perks range from global postcards to signed pieces of art! If you purchase a perk of $100 or more you can select your own piece from the selection of global artists featured this year. Check them out! 

Can’t Donate? Follow us.

Join our mailing list to get updates on new artists. Follow us on FB and Twitter where we will provide updates on our journey. 

Twitter: https://twitter.com/KlawedisJourney

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/klawedis

story:
wedding wave


a social sculpture at stattbad wedding

host / 3ECK, STATTBAD 


project dates

start / July 8th, 2014

opening / August 2nd, 2014

closing / September 6th, 2014 (approximately)


Most crowdfunding campaigns help finance products and provide their donors with certain rewards.

Instead of providing a product, our campaign offers donors the opportunity to be part of a social interaction. Together we would like to live up to and communicate our ideas so that we can achieve and experience a playfull interconnection. 

Beyond the collective work we have created, this is a truly collaborative project and can not exist with out your help. Therefore we are calling for people's support so that we can realize this project independently.

All donors, regardless of how much each individual decides to contribute, will have their name engraved in the surface of The Wave.

 


Für die deutsche Version, bitte folgt dem Link zu unserem Blog:

diewelleimwedding.com


As a dynamic object, The Wave follows Joseph Beuys’ example of working and performing, creating a life-synthesing piece of art that results in a social sculpture, a completed tangible form that is likely to emerge whenever people feel and perceive without judgement. It’s an interactive evolution that does not follow a given scale and can be altered at any second.

The initial idea behind the wave-shaped ramp is clear. It symbolizes a recollection of the skateboard movement's roots: some of the first skateboarders were surfers, surfers who were looking for the perfect wave - even outside the water. As an experienceable object the wave is first of all an oversized skateboard-ramp in the shape of a wave that reminds the spectator of a megaramp. Thanks to its conceptual design, however, it can at the same time be used at a much smaller scale.

The Wave has a wide range of possible uses because of its design and size.

Besides its function as a skate ramp, it is intended to become a platform for a variety of cultural events, such as theatrical performances, movie screenings, classical and modern concerts, exhibitions, readings, and so on.

The intention behind the project is to create a forum for cultural exchange in which anyone can take part. It is a comprehensive piece of art that grows and thrives because of the ongoing events and happenings that take place on the basis of its existence. It is an egalitarian object that invites its own co-creation. Thus the interactive process already begins with a three-week construction period and culminates in the following six-week exhibition phase.



measurements






At a width of 33 feet and a length of 75 feet, the wooden stream poors down into the deep end of the former men's swimming pool, where it hits the blue-tiled wall, slowly rises up, and finally breaks at the breathtaking height of 20 feet. The dynamic power of moving water, icebound within a wooden sculpture. A snapshot. Accessible. Palpable. Playable and tangible. A playground for a whole city.

 

what the money is being used for

15.000 €      / construction wood

10.000 €      / rent Stattbad

  3.000 €      / metal

  2.500 €      / logistics

  2.500 €      / event engineering

  2.000 €      / advertising

  5.000 €      / backup

_______________________________________________________________________

40.000 €      / total


If the amount collected during the campaign exceeds the amount we initially intended to raise, all working participants shall be compensated for their vast effort. The 3ECK Collective would like to keep any other excess funds in order to realise future projects in an uncommercial manner. 

  

 

Please note:

In addition to the so far published events, more events will constantly be added to the list of Perks. The dates for these events are to be announced very soon.


The 3ECK Collective thanks all of you for your donations and considerations.

We look forward to sharing this exciting experience together.


More information can be found on our blog or facebook page.

Blog: diewelleimwedding.com

Facebook: diewelleimwedding / facebook

story:
Help Send Me to Arteles

Hi, I am Lea Devon. Some people know me, many people don't, but I am trying to change that. You see, I feel like I have something to share with the world, and that something is art. My practice is an auto-ethnographical investigation of my life in pursuit of understanding contemporary American culture. My practice is about calling attention to the constructs of American success and the emotional investments we place in possessions and entertainment to create individuality.

I am currently a working artist in Minneapolis, MN. Since moving here for graduate school, I have been awarded many amazing opportunities to share my ideas and passion with people, including a few residencies, group and solo shows, and other collaborative experiences. 

In less than 45 days, I will be boarding a plane on my first international artistic endeavor. I am going to have a one month creative experience at the Arteles residency in scenic Hämeenkyrö, Finland. I have no clue how to pronounce that. Arteles brings together creative minds & professionals from all over the world to sharpen their crafts and to collaborate in a unique setting. This will be a welcomed challenge for me and I look forward to learning and growing but I need your help!
I have graciously received a grant from Arteles for a portion of the fees, but because of the immediacy of this opportunity I fall short for a majority of the expenses. Your contribution would ensure that I can afford airfare there and back (you want to make sure I come home right?), materials for my work, and the rest of the residency fee. 
Want to know more about my work? Please check out Leadevon.com to see what I am working on, and what I have previously created. 
What I Need & What You Get

I need your contribution to help me progress my artistic career, and make art that I believe has an impact on people and the world around me. What you get, besides the obvious satisfaction of helping someone aspiring to fulfill their dreams, is the possibility of owning unique artistic works, or artistic experiences that provide in-depth insights into my thought process and artistic practice. 

/// The funding that I am asking for goes directly to the expenses I have/will incur traveling to Arteles. (Plains, Trains, and Automobiles). Most importantly your funding will go to material cost of creating work at Arteles; that I need to share with you and the world.   

/// In exchange for your support I will be creating specific work that addresses previous projects I have created, re-contextualized, so that you can own parts of them. I will also be making individual pieces, performances, and interjections that can be owned or experienced based solely from this opportunity that I will share with you. 

/// If I do not reach my entire goal, the funds will still be applied to everything I have outlined, so no matter what your contributions will go to me creating new work! 

My promise to you is to try my hardest to make your investment in me a worthwhile endeavor. I have attended several residencies, and maintain a consistent national artistic practice. I am dedicated to becoming someone that influences people positively through artistic intervention. The more I can participate in opportunities like Arteles ensures that my goal of trying to understand why culturally we eat too much, spend too much, and cry at reality television is fully understood and communicated. 

Can't Contribute? Then Help Make Some Noise! 

Broke? I get it! But one way you can help is by passing this along to other people who  see the value of artistic pursuits, and may be able to contribute. 
This is a complicated and hard world to understand, but one thing that consistently brings clarity to all of this complexity is Art. My passion is to be amongst the many people contributing to critical conversations that change and progress the way people understand themselves and their surroundings. What I am asking from you is the chance to keep doing that.

story:
The Toronto Dreams Project

For the last few years, the Toronto Dreams Project has been creating fictional dreams about people from the history of our city. I print them on custom-designed postcards and leave them in the public places where that history happened, so people can find the dreams and learn more about our city’s past.

The response so far has been amazing: the project has been featured in publications like The Toronto Star, Torontoist, and The Globe and Mail, partnered with the Art Gallery of Ontario and Spacing Magazine, and even got an Honourable Mention for a Governor General's Award.

But Toronto’s history is also tied to places all over the world; I’d love to have the chance to leave dreams in some of those places too. So I'm taking the Toronto Dreams Project on the road to visit Toronto-related historical sites in the United Kingdom. That's why I need your help.


The UK Tour

If I can raise $4000, I’ll be able to take the Dreams Project to visit Toronto-related historical sites all over the UK. I’ll leave multiple copies of more than a dozen different dreams in more than a dozen different cities, towns and villages in England and Scotland and Wales. I’ll visit big cities like London, Cardiff and Edinburgh and lesser-known spots like Dunkeswell, Budleigh Salterton and Clackmannanshire.

On top of that, I’ll be using the tour as a chance to share the stories of how these places are connected to the history of Toronto. During the trip, you’ll be able to follow along as I share the stories on my blog and on Facebook, Twitter and Instagram.

So, for example, you’ll get to hear about the hotel in London where Sir John A. Macdonald caught on fire during the negotiations over Confederation, about the psychiatric hospital where one of Toronto’s greatest artists had electroshock therapy, and about a chapel in the middle of the English countryside, which is officially part of the province of Ontario.

If I fall short of raising the full amount, I’ll still try to leave as many dreams as possible in as any many places as possible.


Incentives

As a thank you to everyone who donates at least $20, I’ll send you your very own copy of one of the dreams that I leave in the UK. If you donate $50, I’ll send you 5. And if you donate $100, I’ll be so grateful that I’ll send you your own copy of every single one of the dreams that I leave on the tour.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, you can support the Toronto Dreams Project's UK tour by sharing my crowd-funding campaign on your Facebook page, or on Twitter or Instagram, or even just by telling your friends. I can't tell you how excited I am about this and every little bit helps. Thank you SO much for taking the time to check it out!

print them on custom-designed postcards and leave them in the public places where that history happened,
so people can find the dreams and learn more about our city’s past. The response so far has been amazing: the project has been featured in publications like The Toronto Star, Torontoist, and The Globe and Mail, partnered with the Art Gallery of Ontario and Spacing Magazine, and even got an Honourable Mention for a Governor General's Award.But Toronto’s history is also tied to places all over the
world; I’d love to have the chance to leave dreams in some of those 
places too. So I'm taking the Toronto Dreams Project on the road to visit Toronto-related historical sites in the 
United
Kingdom. That's why I need your help.The UK Tour
If I can raise $4000,
I’ll be able to take the Dreams Project to visit Toronto-related historical
sites all over the UK. I’ll leave multiple copies of more than a
dozen different dreams in more than a dozen different cities, towns and villages
in England and Scotland and Wales. I’ll visit big cities like London, Cardiff
and Edinburgh and lesser-known spots like Dunkeswell, Budleigh Salterton and Clackmannanshire.

On top of that, I’ll be using the tour as a chance to share
the stories of how these places are connected to the history of Toronto. During
the trip, you’ll be able to follow along as I share the stories on my blog and on Facebook, Twitter
and Instagram.So, for example, you’ll get to hear about the hotel in London
where Sir John A. Macdonald caught on fire during the negotiations over Confederation, about the
psychiatric hospital where one of Toronto’s greatest artists had electroshock therapy,
and about a chapel in the middle of the English countryside, which is officially
part of the province of Ontario.If I fall short of raising the full amount, I’ll still try
to leave as many dreams as possible in as any many places as possible.
Incentives

As a thank you to everyone who donates at least $20, I’ll
send you your very own copy of one of the dreams that I leave in the UK. If you donate $50, I’ll send you 5. And
if you donate $100, I’ll be so grateful that I’ll send you your own copy of
every single one of the dreams that I leave on the tour.
Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can't contribute financially, you can support the Toronto Dreams Project's UK tour by sharing my crowd-funding campaign on your Facebook page, or on Twitter or Instagram, or even just by telling your friends. I can't tell you how excited I am about this and every little bit helps. Thank you SO much for taking the time to check it out!

story:
Short Summary

Hi! My name is Amanda, and I am a student at the University of Nebraska at Omaha. I am double majoring in Studio Art and Education, with a concentration in Printmaking, and a minor in Art History. I’m originally from a small town in Iowa, and while I wasn’t afforded many opportunities growing up, I've always had big ambitions. My dream is to create and study art all over the world, and by helping me fund my study abroad I’ll be able to dip my toes in the water, so to speak.

In May I will be travelling to London for two weeks with about 80 other students from my University. This group will be a mix of criminal justice and art history majors, traveling for different aspects of the culture. During this trip we will visit every major museum; cathedral, historical site… basically everything we can with art historical significance. I have never traveled outside of the United States, and this trip is truly a dream come true. 


What We Need & What You Get

Overall, I’ll need about $5,000 to cover the costs of my airfare, lodging, food, as well as spending money and my bills/pet care back home while I’m away, so every little bit helps. If you help me fund this dream trip, not only will you receive my eternal gratitude, but I’ll also be providing a few gifts to show my thanks. These range anywhere from a postcard sent to you during my trip abroad, to a souvenir, to some handmade items that you’ll get before I even step on the plane! Unfortunately I can’t afford anything huge, but I promise the perks you do receive will be full of love and gratitude! If I don’t make my full goal, that’s ok! I can use every penny, and will still be able to go on my trip. The study abroad is charged to my tuition account, and is paid for with my student loans. However, I am accustomed to using that money for bills like rent, electricity, and groceries as I am a full time student. As you can see, this means I still need to raise these funds so that I still have a home to come back to!


The Impact

This trip is important for a young artist like myself because I, and most of the artistic community, believe that one must have a solid base knowledge in art’s history as well as a wide world view in order to create the best work one possibly can. And we all know that art significantly impacts our communities, as well as the world. 


Other Ways You Can Help

I also understand that while some may want to help me fund this adventure, the money just isn’t there. And believe me, asking for money can be really awkward. If you’d still like to help me out, please feel free to share this link and get the word out. Like I said, any little bit counts!

story:
*This is a tax-deductible contribution. You will receive necessary records after the campaign has concluded.*


The DISTILLERY

A Multi-Disciplinary Artist Residency Housed at the New Orleans Contemporary Arts Center

June, 2014

Why The DISTILLERY?

A performing artist continuously redefines how they make work based on the concrete resources of a given environment. Since 2006, over 20 ensemble-based performance companies have formed in New Orleans and stand amongst the established artists that returned post-Katrina. With few traditional theatre houses, very little funding support, no centralized ticketing system, and absent rehearsal spaces, New Orleans performing artists have mounted over 1,000 performances in the past five years. More than half of these performances exhibited original work utilizing ensemble practices, behaviors, and conceptual strategies.

The DISTILLERY exists to support New Orleans artists by providing them with the resources that they need to focus on their creative development.



Here’s How:

The DISTILLERY imagines what 4 New Orleans mid-career artists could achieve if provided local mentorship, national mentorship, rehearsal space, free public showings and a development stipend in a comprehensive 3 month fellowship program at the Contemporary Arts Center, New Orleans (CAC).

The DISTILLERY fellowship captures dynamic processes utilized in the rehearsal room when engaging new creative disciplines.

The DISTILLERY fosters an audience-driven critical dialogue that promotes a sustainable approach to making performance work in a constantly varying environment.



Why Contribute:

The DISTILLERY is currently a pilot program that needs $10,000 to fund our inaugural year. This much-needed funding will go toward mentors, workshops, showcases, documentation, website, and administrative expenses. This funding also serves as a HUGE show of support for a program that we hope to continue next year, the year after, and the year after that…

Your support will ensure that The DISTILLERY will be a sustainable program and that it will have the administrative support that it deserves.

If you can't donate, it is just as important to send this link on to friends and people who love and support arts in New Orleans.

Thank you!



Current Support:

This fellowship will be housed at the Contemporary Arts Center in the summer of 2014. As our partner, the CAC has been generous in the development of The DISTILLERY program as a tool to elevate the opportunities available to local performing artists. The CAC has provided its gorgeous Freeport/McMoRan black box theater as a rehearsal space and venue for public showings, and has offered to finance the fellows' living and material stipends. The CAC is one of New Orleans's largest connections to national and international performing arts and will offer their wisdom and experience in advising program planning and in sourcing mentors and resources.

The DISTILLERY team also received a kick-off grant from the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Foundation to begin our process and get the ball rolling. The Jazz and Heritage Foundation and the Arts Council of New Orleans have offered continuous administrative support with heavy focus on community connections and local resources.



The DISTILLERY 4 Critical Components:

1) MENTORSHIP

Two established New Orleans creative artists will act in The DISTILLERY fellow selection process, fellow development discussions, and fellow public showings. Whether the local established artist shares the same medium as the fellow (puppetry and puppetry) or has seemingly very little in common with the fellow’s medium (puppetry and modern dance), the established artist will provide critical feedback, creative discussion and local resources for each of The DISTILLERY fellows. These two local artists are critical to the development of The DISTILLERY throughout its pilot program and are engaged before the selection process begins and after the fellows conclude the program.

Two established national artists will join The DISTILLERY fellows for one weekend each. During this weekend, there will be a roundtable discussion with our program Creative Consultant Craig Peterson and a free public showing to New Orleans audiences. Following this showing, there will be a roundtable discussion or creative training led by Craig and the visiting artist for the 4 participating fellows. These visiting artists provide further understanding of performance processes and creative resources for each of the three DISTILLERY fellows.

The breakdown:

* Two established New Orleans artistic mentors

* Two visiting, nationally recognized artistic mentors

* Four documented roundtable discussions with mentors and our Creative Consultant



2) CROSS-DISCIPLINE EXCHANGE

The DISTILLERY is specifically interested in interdisciplinary, cross-collaborative process and performance. When fellows are selected, a 10-page research statement on the process and medium of their performance work is written and considered. This statement is publicly shared on our Roundtable Archive and critically considered by the fellow, the group of fellows, the mentors and the audiences.

Throughout the three-month program, the fellows will meet with each of the established local New Orleans artists twice. These meetings may be an intersection of two different mediums of performance crafting critical dialogue together. There will be written reflections of these meetings shared in the Roundtable Archive. The DISTILLERY will encourage fellows to explore the established New Orleans artist’s unique medium in their own rehearsal room.

Program staff will select two national artists that speak to recurring themes in all three fellows’ work. The two weekend-long visits by these national artists will further incite possibilities for interdisciplinary performance. Creative Consultant will also reflect and archive themes, challenges and creative potentials that he sees in the meetings on our online archival forum.

The DISTILLERY will pull developing artists out of the often isolated development environment and instead encourage artists to develop and challenge their point of view in the context of a larger artist community.

The breakdown:

*Selected fellows construct a 10-page researched statement about their unique medium/process

* Fellows interact with established local artists’ mediums critically and practically

* Fellows interact with nationally recognized artists critically and practically

* Fellows interact with the program Creative Consultant critically and practically.



3) ROUNDTABLE EVALUATIONS

Many New Orleans artists have stepped into rehearsal to craft a mode of approaching new interdisciplinary work, but few have archived that process for further critical conversation. The DISTILLERY prioritizes archiving these processes in order to promote performance literacy for fellow artists, potential presenters and audiences. To begin this, all 4 DISTILLERY fellows will specify the process and research resources during his or her time with The DISTILLERY in a 10-page research statement. The more defined the research and process is, the more creative potential there will be for cross-discipline interaction. These statements will be made public in an online archival forum (inspired by Howlround).

As The DISTILLERY fellows and established local artists critically interact, written blogs or journals by these mid-career and established artists will further articulate the converging of performance mediums.

Finally, the Creative Consultant will share critical responses in a written archive format to capture the cross-disciplinary moments that hold creative potential when performing artists of different mediums articulate, collaborate, and reflect.

The breakdown:

* 4 fellows craft a 10-page research statement about their own unique medium/process

* Dedicated writing/reflection time Saturdays from 10am – Noon in the Spun Cafe.

* Writings reflect the rehearsal process, the exchanges with established local and national mentor artists, audience engagement, and other prompts issued by the program.

* Contributing writers are the 4 fellows, established local artists/mentors, Creative Consultant, Project Facilitator, Project Manager, and audiences

* All writings are posted and managed in an online archival forum



4) AUDIENCE ENGAGEMENT

Positively, New Orleans’ lack of traditional theatre spaces has created neighborhood pockets of performance with unique modes of audience engagement. New Orleans’ 30+ companies, artists and ensembles have developed their own processes and abilities of sustaining over 1,000 performances in the past five years. The DISTILLERY hosted at the CAC gathers these dispersed audiences into a central location for contemporary interdisciplinary performance – and asks for their critical feedback. These high quality conversations will not only increase the literacy amongst the audience community at the CAC, but extend back into the unique pockets of audiences throughout New Orleans.

On three Friday nights during the three-month program, the CAC will hold process showings free to the public including wine and food. Each performer will show 15 – 25 minutes of work they are developing while in The DISTILLERY program. The public showings will be hosted by Project Manager Alysia Savoy and/or Creative Consultant Craig Peterson and ask the audiences to consider the processes utilized and critically respond to the results. In the lobby of the CAC will be displayed the archived roundtable writings as they evolve from the fellows, established artists, and Craig. The DISTILLERY promotes complete process transparency to promote literacy and critical audience feedback.

At the end of the three-month program, The DISTILLERY fellows will be asked to compose an outline for further engaging their unique audiences into the process of creating their work. These outlines will be publicly shared on our online archival forum.

The breakdown:

* 3 free “work in process” showings at the CAC

* Showings present 15-25 minutes of developing performance work from each fellow

* Roundtable archive reflections, inspirations, conversations are displayed in the lobby

* Concluding, 4 fellows craft outline promoting audience engagement in future development

* Outlines/statement are shared publicly on the online archival forum



Who is The DISTILLERY:

Fellows:

Aurora Nealand is a New Orleans musician, sound designer, street performer and overall Queen of all trades. For The DISTILLERY she will explore Female Hysteria: A Quest for Authentic Manhood and question, sonically: what do women lose about their natural hysteria in the common workplace?

Michael Quess? Moore is a performer, teacher, social advocate, and an award-winning slam-poet. For The DISTILLERY he will explore Crossroads: an original play about the intersection of race and gentrification in the larger institutional landscape, questioning the impact of privilege and how oppression is a precursor to reactionary violence.

Evan Spigelman is an actor, lighting designer, and queer performance artist donning the persona of dada drag queen Miss Asa Metric. For The DISTILLERY, he will explore Miss Asa Metric while she explores a Queer History of Punk through testimonies of fellow New Orleanians and created by ensemble building.

Maritza Mercado-Narcisse is a dancer and choreographer. While at The DISTILLERY she will explore I Won't Leave the Naming Up to You, an investigation of family secrets and half-truths spread through generations utilizing video, music and dance.


Mentors:

Sherri Marina is an actress, educator, and potato chip addict with over 20 years experience. She currently resides in New Orleans, LA and is a proud member of Actor’s Equity Association. Sherri holds a MFA from The University of Iowa and a BFA from Kent State University. Sherri was the Chair of the Department of Theatre at Dillard University from 2001 – 2010.

Jeff Becker is a director, designer and sculptor based in New Orleans. He received his BFA from Alfred University and an MFA from The Ohio State University. He co-founded CRISUS, a performance group that specialized in site-specific performances that utilized innovative kinetic sets, sculpture, film, and machines. He has continued working in this way as an ensemble member of ArtSpot Productions that creates site-responsive devised theater.



Staff:

Nina Nichols is the Manager of Resources and Development for The DISTILLERY. She is a theater and visual artist, performer, and president of The Black Forest Fancies 501c3. 

Alysia Savoy is The DISTILLERY Project Manager and a freelance arts administrator living and working in New Orleans.

Emilie Whelan is The DISTILLERY Program Facilitator. She is a New Orleans director, actor, art administrator, and a member of Cripple Creek Theatre Company. She is currently a candidate of UC San Diego's Graduate Directing Program under Gabor Tompa.

Craig T. Peterson is The DISTILLERY Creative Consultant. He is a Philadelphia-based independent producer and consultant with twenty years of experience as a curator, cultural organizer, and programmer of contemporary performing arts.

story:
All artwork in the video are projects that will be activities at the Color of Faith workshops.

Welcome to the Color of Faith campaign page! My name is Heather Kasdan and I am a graduate student at the Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore. I am working towards my MFA in Community Arts. Color of Faith is my thesis project.

I designed the Color of Faith as a series of workshops that I will be facilitating in partnership with various places of worship in Baltimore City. Together, our creation of expressive art projects will serve as a vehicle for deeper conversation about faith as a tool for learning, spiritual growth, and community building. Participants in this program will create a collaborative piece of art for their own congregation as well as explore other religions by sharing their artwork with others.


Color of Faith will have three components:

Workshops

  • I will be facilitating between 4-6 workshops with each participating congregation.

  • The partnering congregations so far: Amazing Grace Lutheran Church and Rosh Pina Messianic Synagogue. 

Collaborative Art Piece

  • Each participating workshop group from every partnering congregation will create an art piece that will be displayed permanently at its own place of worship.

  • Participants will create something to enrich their place of worship.

Color Palettes

  • Color of Faith will provide workshops addressing new ways of thinking about the arts, religion and faith, and symbolism. Creating color palettes for religion and personal faith is one example of the activities.

  • Along with facilitating workshops I will be creating art with these religious communities. I will use the color palettes from each participant to create a larger piece of work.


My Inspiration:

Religious art can still be found in congregational settings. Stained glass windows, Torah arks, and the overall architecture of the space can create arts-based meaning for a religious group. However in the Art and Religion survey, conducted by Robert Wunthnow in 1999, 65.1% said that places of worship should do more to encourage their members' creativity and imagination. Color of Faith will serve as a vehicle for deeper conversations about faith and religion. Expressive art projects, storytelling, and art-sharing amongst and about the different participating religious groups will encourage a real “creativity of faith,” cross-cultural understanding and new collective meaning.

Where the money will go:

  • Art Supplies

  • Workshop Needs (Refreshments, Collaborative Art Project, etc.)

  • Printing

  • Transportation

    ** We have reached our 100% goal! Donations over our goal will continue to go towards the programming of Color of Faith and events at the congregation at the end of each of their programs. 

**If you are unable to contribute money but would still like to support Color of Faith, please spread the word to your family and friends! Stay tuned for updates of the program and the artwork being created by visiting my blog.

as a series of workshops that I will be facilitating in partnership
with various places of worship in Baltimore City. Together, our
creation of expressive art projects will serve as a vehicle for
deeper conversation about faith as a tool for learning, spiritual
growth, and community building. Participants in this program will
create a collaborative piece of art for their own congregation as
well as explore other religions by sharing their artwork with others.


Color of Faith will
have three components:

Workshops


I
	will be facilitating between 4-6 workshops with each participating
	congregation.


The
	partnering congregations so far: Amazing Grace Lutheran Church and Rosh Pina Messianic Synagogue. 


Collaborative Art
Piece


Each
	participating workshop group from every partnering congregation will
	create an art piece that will be displayed permanently at its own
	place of worship. 
	


Participants
	will create something to enrich their place of worship.


Color Palettes


Color
	of Faith will
	provide workshops addressing new ways of thinking about the arts,
	religion and faith, and symbolism. Creating color palettes for
	religion and personal faith is one example of the activities. 
	


Along
	with facilitating workshops I will be creating art with these
	religious communities. I will use the color palettes from each
	participant to create a larger piece of work. 
	





My Inspiration: 

	Religious
art can still be found in congregational settings. Stained glass
windows, Torah arks, and the overall architecture of the space can
create arts-based  meaning for a religious group. However in the Art
and Religion survey, conducted by Robert Wunthnow in 1999, 65.1% said
that places of worship should do more to encourage their members'
creativity and imagination. Color
of Faith will
serve 
as a vehicle for deeper conversations about faith and religion.
Expressive art projects, storytelling, and art-sharing amongst and
about the different participating religious groups will encourage a
real “creativity of faith,” cross-cultural understanding and new
collective meaning. 


Where the money will
go:


Art
	Supplies


Workshop
	Needs (Refreshments, Collaborative Art Project, etc.)


Printing
	
	


Transportation
** We have reached our 100% goal! Donations over our goal will continue to go towards the programming of Color of Faith and events at the congregation at the end of each of their programs. 


**If
you are unable to contribute money but would still like to support
Color
of Faith,
please spread the word to your family and friends! Stay tuned for
updates of the program and the artwork being created by visiting my
blog.
